Award.AwardTitle: Tracking Cell Fate during Mechanically Directed Bone Regeneration In Vivo

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to quantify the mechanical environment of a bone injury and its association with the response of skeletal progenitor cells at the injury site. Skeletal progenitor cells play a principal role in healing of bone fractures and other skeletal injuries and can differentiate into one of multiple, committed cell types depending on stimuli in their local environment. The planned studies will apply a combination of experimental and computational tools from engineering and biology to label progenitor cells at the injury site, to quantify the mechanical environment of the tissues in which these cells reside, and to identify the specific mechanical stimuli (e.g., shear strain, pressure, etc.) associated with the recruitment of these cells and their various fates. These studies will define the mechanical conditions highly favorable to formation of a given type of skeletal tissue, such as bone, cartilage, and fibrous tissue.

These studies will accelerate the pace of discovery in several areas of basic and clinical research, including defining mechanical environments that can promote bone healing, uncovering the mechanisms by which mechanical stimuli can influence cell differentiation, and identifying new classes of molecular targets for enhancing bone formation. Each of these avenues is directed towards alleviating the personal and economic costs arising from bone injuries, and in particular, from poor healing of these injuries. The educational components of the project consist of training of junior scientists and engineers-two graduate students and three undergraduate students will be mentored on this research project-and on enhancing a successful, residential summer program for low-income, high-school girls interested in scientific and quantitative fields of study. Content for the program is supplied by university faculty and staff, industry partnerships, and outreach modules designed by undergraduate and graduate students enrolled in courses in engineering mechanics and biomechanics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bone repair is one of the only tissues in the human body with a true capacity for regeneration. However, many factors limit this regenerative capacity, making repair of bone injuries a major clinical problem. Some of these factors, such as the presence of diabetes, are known, while others have yet to be defined. Although it is well established that bone repair depends on mechanical “cues” (forces, deformations, pressures, etc.) present at the injury site during healing, current understanding of how these cues affect repair, or even of what cues are most potent, is limited.

 

This project addressed this gap in knowledge in two ways. First, we used tools in genetics and molecular biology to elucidate the contribution of a particular type of cell to the healing process. Second, we used tools from mechanical engineering to identify the mechanical cues experienced during healing by the tissues in which these cells reside.

 

The results have advanced fundamental understanding of how bones heal. We identified that a specific genetic marker, Prx1, is present in cells in a diverse set of tissues—bone, cartilage, fibrous tissue, muscle—that span the injury site. These results suggest that the particular population(s) of cells that this marker identifies contribute to bone repair more broadly than had previously been recognized. This marker thus provides a tool for future studies of the effects of various treatments on accelerating bone healing. In addition, our studies produced some of the first data on the mechanical microenvironment associated with formation of specific tissues during bone healing. These data reveal that bone formation is more likely to form at lower shear strains and fibrous tissue is more likely to form at higher shear strains. These results have important implications for clinical management of bone injuries, in terms of designing and selecting methods of stabilizing bone injuries to target a particular range of shear strains.

 

Along with the impact of this project on developing effective approaches to enhancing bone repair, the project activities have included workforce development and community outreach. Nine individuals, ranging from undergraduate to Ph.D. students, received technical training and mentorship through this project. Partial funding was provided to augment a successful outreach program for high-school girls interested in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM). As part of the project, we carried out a ten-year retrospective study of the program. This study included web surveys and follow-up phone interviews conducted by an independent emissary trained in education and psychology. The strengths and weaknesses identified through the study have been used to improve the format and content of the program, which will be offered for the 12th consecutive year in July 2018.
